author: msawyers@times-news.com(Michael A Sawyers)
title: Guide's death prompts investigation of state hunting license exemption
text:
by Michael A Sawyers 
HENDERSON — Ballistic tests are taking place to help the Maryland Natural Resources Police determine which of two boys fired the shot that killed a hunting guide on the Eastern Shore on Oct. 10, according to an agency official. 
At 4:30 p.m. that day, Marvin Bowen Coppage , 75, Centreville, was struck in the face, neck and right shoulder by a blast from a 20-gauge shotgun. 
He was pronounced dead at the scene, according to Candy Thomson, NRP public information officer. 
Investigators have not yet determined the distance of the victim from the shooter, Thomson said. 
The hunt took place at Schrader’s Outdoors, a commercial hunting operation near Henderson in Queen Anne’s County. 
Both boys were hunting with 20-gauge shotguns. 
Coppage was guiding a group of four hunters, one adult and three juveniles — a 13-year-old from Great Falls, Va., a 14-year-old from Lanham and a 16-year-old from Woodlands, Texas. 
Thomson said the 13-year-old and 14-year-old each shot at a flushing bird, but pellets from only one gun struck Coppage. 
“Another guide performed CPR until the Queen Anne’s County EMS arrived,” Thomson said on Monday, adding that Coppage was wearing a blaze orange hat and vest at the time he was shot. 
It was unclear Monday afternoon if either of the two shooters had taken and passed hunter education courses. 
Stephen Schatz, DNR’s director of communication, said he had learned from NRP that some in the hunting party had passed such courses, but had not been made aware of their identities. 
The commercial hunting site where the incident took place is licensed by DNR as a regulated shooting area. 
No license required 
According to the Maryland Guide to Hunting & Trapping 2015/2016, hunters on RSAs are not required to have a state hunting license. 
The purchase of a state hunting license is allowed only after successful passage of a hunter education course, except for older hunters who have been grandfathered into the system. 
Schatz also said the Office of the Attorney General is studying the matter to determine if the hunting license exemption for RSAs as stated in the printed hunting guide is supported by state law. 
This is the second time a juvenile hunter has shot a person in Maryland this year. The first was in April when a Pennsylvania man hunting turkeys on the Green Ridge State Forest was shot. That victim survived.
